comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From the 1911 census: Murdoch Robert, 39, Major Retired Murdoch, Florence, 37, Wife, Children Born: 5 Living: 4 Murdoch,Adeline, 9, Daughter Murdoch,Sidney, 8, Son Murdoch, Robert, 1, Son That was April, 1911, so in September 1905, Sidney would be about 3, and Adeline would be 4. I don't know who the older girl is (yet!). From the London Gazette: 3rd Battalion, The Royal Irish Regiment... Captain Robert Murdoch is granted the honorary: rank of Major. Dated 2nd April, 1908. Captain and Honorary Major Robert Murdoch resigns his Commission, with permission to retain his rank, and to wear the prescribed uniform. Dated 3rd April, 1908. So in the 1901 census, he would have been an officer still, but the children wer born in Tipperary, so let's keep looking... Aha! Here they are in the 1901 census. at the outlaws place, no sign of the older girl...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Robert Murdoch, Gent., to be Second Lieutenant. Dated 18th March, 1891.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In 1906 Robert Murdock held over 2,500 acres of untenanted land at Bohrnarnane and Cloheenfishoge in county Tipperary.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The family occupied 24 rooms in a house in 1911, which I think must be Kilcoran Lodge. Now a Hotel: Streetview

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Major R Murdoch was still around in 1930, at the unveiling of a War Memorial in Cahir.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here are the folks getting hitched in 1897.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Could this be the older girl? Early 20th Century Irish School "Portrait of a Lady holding a bouquet of Flowers," The sitter is reputed to be Caroline Murdock, born Kilcoran Lodge, Co. Tipperary, and was daughter of Lt. Col. Robert Murdock of Cahir, and is reputed to be the first Lady to receive a jockeys licence in Ireland, O.O.C., indistinctly signed with initials, 13.5in x 9.5in (34cms x 24cms). (1) A jockey's licence!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: London Times, October 31st 1933. Parents still alive (otherwise it would be 'the late ...')

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: And Sidney is still in Kenya in 1953 - The October 1953 Kenya Gazette mentions him as a freehold owner in Mombasa in connection with The Municipalities and Townships (Private Streets) Ordinance 1951 Kenya Gazette

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Outgoing passenger lists show a Sidney John Murdoch (born 1903) travelling from London to Mombasa in 1927,  1938, and 1948, and a Helen Mary Murdoch making the same trip in 1938 and 1949. Helen Rudd went from Southampton to Mombasa in 1930

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: On 4th Dec 1934 Sidney and Helen Murdoch (occupation 'settler') , aged 32 and 33, sailed on the Llanstephan Castle from Mombasa to London.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
The parents were married 12th January 1897, so assuming no ahem-ahem family website, the oldest girl is just eight

In fact, this could plausibly be on the occasion of her eighth birthday!

In April 1911 (the census) she would be 13, and away at boarding school, perhaps, but I wonder where she was in 1901?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Major R Murdoch put Kilcoran Lodge up for sale in 1939. An advertisement in the London Times on Jun 17 1939 describes it as "an attractive modern residence with beautiful gardens, 70 acres woodland" and lists the rooms and gardens in great detail (and all in the glowing terms typical of estate agents).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Laughing at ahem-ahem family website before the watershed!

But laughing aside, thank you and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] for great identification work...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Still baffled by the Mystery of the Disappearing Murdoch (perhaps Caroline). If she was at boarding school, how come she's not coming up on the 1911 census (unless sent off to school in England)? Plus there's a governess living with the Murdochs, presumably teaching Adeline, showing up in 1911. Why would "Caroline" be sent away, and not Adeline? Hate to ask this, but there's no way she could be dead by 1911, is there? "5 children, 4 living"? P.S. I checked for lady jockeys in the Irish Times for the first couple of decades of the 20th century, but could only unearth some American women...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 109065215@N04
comment._content: I believe these Murdochs are some of my long lost cousins.

comment.author: 109065215@N04
comment._content: According to my research their father, Maj. Robt Murdock, was the son of Dr. Sidney Murdock (1841-1881) & Mary Adelaide Jacob (1844-1933). Sidney Murdock was the son of Robert Murdock (?-1868) and Prudentia Cunningham (1803-1869). Prudentia was the daughter of Joseph Cunningham (no dates) and Dorothy or Dorothea Jackson (c1780-?). Dorothy, or Dorothea, Jackson was the daughter of John Jackson of Crieve (1744-1824) and Sarah Brunker (1753-1820). John Jackson was the son of Hugh Jackson (1709-1777) and Ellinor Galt, or Gault (1711-1791). These last two were my ggggg grandparents. Crieve is nearby Ballybay, Co. Monaghan, and was later owned by the Murdocks, in addition to their lands in Tip. The family's last name was spelled Murdock or Murdoch. I'd love to get in touch with kilcorn_uk.

comment.author: 11701858@N05
